A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.
Does the concept of a/an Commutative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Finitely generated module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a finitely generated module involves the existence of a finite set of generators such that every element of the module can be expressed as a linear combination of these generators. This definition focuses on the ability to generate all elements of the module from a finite set and does not inherently require the operation in the module to be commutative.

The commutative law, on the other hand, pertains to the property of a binary operation being commutative, meaning that the order of operation does not affect the result. This property is not necessary for the definition of a finitely generated module. A module can be finitely generated regardless of whether the operation within the module or the ring it is over is commutative.

Therefore, the concept of the commutative law is not required for the definition of a finitely generated module to make sense. The essential aspect of a finitely generated module is the existence of a finite generating set, not the commutativity of the operations involved.
